questions.text: Which of the following lists comprises bones that are part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clavicle, Fibula,  Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius

 

Option B.

 

  • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular system)
  • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular system)
  • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular system)
  • This list contains bones from appendicular skeletons only, hence it is answer.
  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial skeleton
    • Appendicular skeleton
  • All bones of axial & appendicular system are shown in below image

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia

 

  • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum

 

  • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Scapula (Shoulder Blade) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Occipital is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Metacarpals are the bones in the hand, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Sternum (Breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal

 

  • Ulna is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalanges are the finger and toe bones, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Mandible (Lower Jawbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Coxal (Hip Bone) is part of the pelvic girdle of the appendicular skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial Skeleton
    • Appendicular Skeleton
      • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular System)
      • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular System)
      • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular System)

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 66

choices.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

 

Option B:

 

  • The “Plate” is the Hyaline Cartilage between the Shaft (Diaphysis) and End (Epiphysis) of a Long bone in Children and Adolescents.
  • The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.
  • In Adults it is replaced by an ossified “Epiphyseal Line”.

 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone. The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity.

 

Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone.  While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis, it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation.

 

Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal, or medullary cavity, is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

choices.text: The Palms of the Hands are facing Posteriorly.
The Feet are dorsiflexed at the ankles.

questions.text: Concept of “Anatomical Position” is very essential for all kind of operative procedure and to understand and publish the articles.  About anatomical position, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) The Thumbs are oriented Laterally.

 

This question is about the basic anatomical position of the human body.

 

Option B. The thumbs are indeed oriented laterally. This is a defining characteristic of the anatomical position, and it helps provide consistency in anatomical descriptions.

 

  • The anatomical position is a standardized reference posture used in anatomical and all medical & surgical descriptions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The palms of the hands are facing anteriorly, not posteriorly. This allows for a clear view of the anatomical structures of the body.

 

Option C. The feet are not dorsiflexed at the ankles in the anatomical position. Instead, they are in a neutral position, with the toes pointing forward.

 

Option D. The elbows are not fully flexed; they are extended in the anatomical position but not fully. This extension allows for accurate descriptions of the upper limb’s anatomical relationships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the anatomical position, the thumbs are oriented laterally. This position serves as a standardized reference for describing the location and orientation of anatomical structures in the human body.

 

Ref: BD Chaurasia’s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7th edition, Page no- 11, 12

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Remnant of Panniculus Carnosus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmaris Longus

 

Option B: Palmaris longus is not a remnant of panniculus carnosus. Palmaris longus muscle is present beneath deep fascia over the flexor surface of forearm and its tendon expands to form the palmar aponeurosis in hand. Palmaris brevis present subcutaneously over the hypothenar eminence is a remnant of panniculus carnosus.

 

Penniculus carnosus is a thin sheet of muscles present in subcutaneous fascias in lower animals.

 

Its remnants in humans include

  1. Muscles of facial expressions
  2. platysma 
  3. Subareolar muscle of breast
  4. Palmaris brevis
  5. Dartos in scrotum
  6. Corrugator cutis ani
  7. Auricularis anterior

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Dartos is a subcutaneous smooth muscle present beneath the skin of scrotum, innervated by sympathetic fibres.

 

Option C: Occipitofrontalis subcutaneous muscle of the scalp innervated by facial nerve, its contraction moves the scalp forwards and backwards. The frontal belly of the occipitofrontalis is innervated by temporal branch of facial nerve. Occipital belly by posterior auricular branch of facial nerve

 

Option D: Auricularis anterior subcutaneous muscle of the auricle is innervated by temporal branch of facial nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palmaris longus muscle is present beneath deep fascia over the flexor surface of forearm and its tendon expands to form the palmar aponeurosis in hand. Palmaris brevis present subcutaneously over the hypothenar eminence is a remnant of panniculus carnosus.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 77

questions.text: In the context of young bones, which part is primarily responsible for longitudinal growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate

 

It is present between metaphysis and epiphysis in the growing bone. Once the complete fusion of this plate takes place the growth also stops.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diaphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis.
  • It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.

 

Option B. Epiphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis.
  • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability, it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.

 

Option C. Metaphysis 

 

  • Metaphysis is the part of the bone between diaphysis and growth plate in the growing bone and in the adult bone it lies between diaphysis and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

questions.text: A 50-year-old female went to her family physician with complaints of pain over her lower neck for the past 2 months. The pain had increased over the past three days. She insisted that an x-ray should be taken. The given image is the x-ray of the patient. Which of the following is not a feature of cervical vertebra?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vertebral Foramen is Small & Circular

 

Option B:

 

  • Vertebral foramen is large & triangular for accomodation of cervical enlargement of spinal cord.
     

   

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is true. The uncinate processes, also known as the uncus or uncal process, are hook-shaped processes on the lateral edges of the top surface of the bodies of the third to the seventh cervical vertebrae. They are involved in the formation of the uncovertebral joints (joints of Luschka), which are unique to the cervical spine, the upper surface of which presents with raised lips called uncal process.

 

Option C: This is true for most cervical vertebrae (C2-C6). The spinous processes of these vertebrae are typically short and bifid (split at the end), which is a distinctive feature of cervical vertebrae, allowing for greater movement and muscle attachment.

 

Option D: This is true. The cervical vertebrae are unique in having the foramen transversarium within each transverse process. These foramina serve as passages for the vertebral arteries (except for the seventh cervical vertebra, where the foramen transversarium may transmit only accessory veins rather than the artery).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vertebral foramen in cervical vertebrae is actually relatively large and triangular (or heart-shaped) to accommodate the cervical enlargement of the spinal cord.

  • This feature is more characteristic of thoracic vertebrae, where the vertebral foramen tends to be smaller and more circular. Therefore, option B is not a feature of cervical vertebrae.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 720

Ans. A) Mylohyoid

 

Option A: The mylohyoid muscle is part of the oral diaphragm. It forms the muscular floor of the mouth and helps support the tongue, allowing for various functions such as swallowing and speech. It is an important component of the oral diaphragm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Genioglossus arises from the superior genial tubercles of mandible and form the bulk of tongue inserting into it from root to its apex. The genioglossus is responsible for protruding and retracting the tongue. While it plays a crucial role in tongue movement and speech, it is not part of the oral diaphragm.

 

Option C: Hyoglossus muscles divides the lingual artery into three parts. The hyoglossus is involved in tongue movement. It assists in depressing and retracting the tongue. Like the genioglossus, it is not part of the oral diaphragm.

 

Option D: The buccinator muscle is located in the cheek and plays a role in compressing the cheeks against the teeth, aiding in actions like blowing air and keeping food in the mouth. It is not part of the oral diaphragm. Buccinator is a muscle of the cheek innervated by facial nerve

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mylohyoid muscle originates from the mylohyoid line of mandible and inserts. The fibers slope downward and medially, posterior 1/4th fibres is inserted into body of hyoid bone and anterior 3/4th fibres interdigitate in a median fibrous raphe. The mylohyoid muscle of both sides form a gutter shaped floor of the mouth and support the weight of the tongue, hence called diaphragm a orris. It divides the submandibular gland into a superficial and deep part.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 176

choices.text: The median atlantoaxial joint is a hinge synovial joint
The lateral atlantoaxial joint is a plane synovial joint
The alar ligaments rupture in death due to judicial hanging
Apical ligament extends from dens to the posterior margin of foramen magnum

questions.text: The convicts of a gang rape case currently locked up in jail will be soon executed their death sentence as per the judgement. As per Indian laws hanging is the only mode of executing a death sentence for civilians. Which of the following statements is true in relation to the pointed structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The alar ligaments rupture in death due to judicial hanging

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is the second cervical vertebra - Axis vertebra

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. There are 3 synovial joints between the atlas and axis-one median & two lateral joints. The median atlantoaxial joint is a pivot joint.

 

Option B. lateral atlantoaxial joints participate in rotation of the head and also transmit the weight of the skull through atlanto occipital joints.

 

Option D. Apical ligament of dens extends from tip of dens to basilar part of occipital bone close to anterior margin of foramen magnum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In death due to judicial hanging there is either rupture of transverse ligament or fracture of dens, as a result the atlas is dislocated from axis and compress spinal cord with fatal outcome

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 58
